required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Pharmacokinetics of Apricitabine and Tipranavir When Dosed Alone or Together
clinical_study.official_title: A Phase I, Open Label, Controlled, Intra-subject Comparison Study to Investigate the Effect of Co-administration Upon the Pharmacokinetics of Tipranavir (Ritonavir Boosted) and Apricitabine.

brief_summary.textblock: The aim of the study is to see if apricitabine or tipranavir affect the levels of each other in the blood (pharmacokinetic interaction) when they are dosed together.

detailed_description.textblock: Apricitabine is a new NRTI in development for treatment of drug resistant HIV. Tipranavir is a recently licensed protease inhibitor for treatment of drug resistant HIV. Tipranavir affects the plasma concentration of some other drugs when they are used together with tipranavir. This study will examine whether the pharmacokinetics of apricitabine are changed when it is dosed together with tipranavir compared to apricitabine alone. Also, the pharmacokinetics of tipranavir will be examined at steady state when it is dosed alone and when it is dosed together with apricitabine. Information on the safety and tolerability of the two drugs when dosed together will also be obtained.

primary_outcome.measure: To compare the single dose pharmacokinetics of apricitabine when administered alone and in the presence of steady state concentrations of tipranavir 500 mg administered twice daily in combination with ritonavir 200 mg twice daily.

secondary_outcome.measure: To compare the steady state pharmacokinetics of tipranavir 500 mg administered twice daily with ritonavir 200mg in the presence and absence of apricitabine.
To evaluate the safety and tolerability of apricitabine administered in combination with tipranavir and ritonavir.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- healthy males 18-40 years old
- non-smokers
- no clinically significant medical history
Exclusion Criteria:
- current or relevant previous medical history of significance
- hepatitis B, hepatitis C, or HIV positive
- current use of prescription or OTC medications
- use of illicit substances or alcohol (>14 drinks/week)
